awd_titl_txt: TWC SBE: Option: Frontier: Collaborative: Towards Effective Web Privacy Notice and Choice: A Multi-Disciplinary Prospective
awd_abstract_narration:
Natural language privacy policies have become a de facto standard to address expectations of notice and choice on the Web. Yet, there is ample evidence that users generally do not read these policies and that those who occasionally do struggle to understand what they read. Initiatives aimed at addressing this problem through the development of machine implementable standards or other solutions that require website operators to adhere to more stringent requirements have run into obstacles, with many website operators showing reluctance to commit to anything more than what they currently do. This project offers the prospect of overcoming the limitations of current natural language privacy policies without imposing new requirements on website operators.

This frontier project builds on recent advances in natural language processing, privacy preference modeling, crowdsourcing, formal methods, and privacy interfaces to overcome this situation.  It combines fundamental research with the development of scalable technologies to semi-automatically extract key privacy policy features from natural language website privacy policies and present these features to users in an easy-to-digest format that enables them to make more informed privacy decisions as they interact with different websites.  Work in this project also involves the systematic collection and analysis of website privacy policies, looking for trends and deficiencies both in the wording and content of these policies across different sectors and using this analysis to inform ongoing public policy debates. An important part of this project is to work closely with stake holders in industry to enable the transfer of these technologies to industry for large-scale deployment.

por.por_cntn:
Natural language privacy policies have become a de facto standard to address expectations of ?notice and choice? online. Yet, there is ample evidence that users generally do not read these policies and that those who occasionally do struggle to understand what they read. As an increasing amount of our activities are moving online and as we interact with a growing number of online services and access these services from devices such as smartphones, which are even less conducive to reading privacy policies, this situation will only get worse. Moreover, privacy policies continue to be one of the few instruments used by U.S. regulators to monitor and encourage better privacy practices. Initiatives aimed at addressing this problem through the development of machine implementable standards or other solutions that require website operators to adhere to more stringent requirements have run into obstacles, with many website operators showing reluctance to commit to anything more than what they currently do.

Recent advances in natural language processing, privacy preference modeling, crowdsourcing, and privacy interfaces suggest however that it may be possible to overcome this challenge and develop practical solutions that rely on existing natural language privacy policies rather than impose new requirements on website operators. This frontier project explored this possibility through a combination of fundamental research in these areas along with the development and evaluation of novel tools for semi-automatically extracting key privacy policy features and presenting these policy features in an effective (and possibly personalized) manner to users.

Findings from this research have demonstrated the viability of several semi-automated and fully automated privacy policy annotation techniques and in the process paved the way to new approaches for leveraging privacy policies. This includes opening the way to the development of new privacy browser plug-ins, new techniques to help companies, app stores and regulators to check for privacy policy compliance issues at scale. They also open the door to studies looking at historical trends in the text of privacy policies, studies comparing privacy policies within and across sectors, and much more.

By presenting our research results in academic, industry and public policy circles, we have aimed to disseminated the results of the research as broadly as possible. This has included participation in technical conferences (e.g., EMNLP), participation in public policy conferences (e.g., International Computers, Privacy, and Data Protection Conference; Privacy Law Scholars Conference, European Privacy Law Scholars Conference, Northeast Privacy Scholars Workshop). It has also included close interactions with regulators (e.g, Federal Trade Commission) and industry (e.g., AT&T, Google).

Modified by: Thomas Norton
